original_title: Making a Solder Paste Stencil From What You Have On Hand
original_content:
Sometimes there are moments when an engineer has to use whatever materials they have to hand in order to complete the job on time. Such a situation arose at the RevSpace hacker space in Den Haag, Netherlands, as they were the assembly venue for a conference badge.
Their problem was that the badge PCB had no solder paste stencil, and the solution was to laser cut one out of an unexpected material. The backing paper for self-adhesive vinyl sheet has properties not unlike those desired of a stencil, so they tried laser-cutting one from that material. The result was a robust stencil that outperformed the Mylar they had previously used, enabled the manufacture of 350 boards.
They think that the polymer layer on top of the paper may be silicone, and found that the laser didnt unduly melt the edges of the cut. Were not sure wed feed random unknown plastics into our cutter, were guessing they have good quality ventilation. Its mounted into a plywood jig in much the same way as a conventional stencil might be.
The badges were destined for WICCON, a Dutch conference from an organisation for women in cybersecurity. Sadly weve not seen a completed one so were not sure what it does, however were pleased to hear they were completed before the event. Thats a hurdle all badge designers will know well.
Long term readers may remember, that RevSpace have something of a history when it comes to assembling badges.
title: レーザーカットで作成されたマイラーと同等性能のステンシル
body: RevSpaceハッカースペースでは、会議バッジの組み立て会場として活用されました。バッジのPCBにははんだペーストステンシルがなかったため、予想外の素材でレーザーカットしました。自己粘着ビニールシートの下敷きがステンシルとして適していたため、これを使用しました。製造された350枚のボードには、これまで使用していたMylarを上回るパフォーマンスの堅牢なステンシルが使用されました。完成したバッジの機能は分かりませんが、イベント前に完成したことは喜ばしいことです。RevSpaceはバッジの組み立てにおいてその経験を持っています。
